awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Simulating Demand and Competition for Emerging Transportation Modes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the state-of-the-art for demand modeling for electric aircraft by developing a decision support tool that assesses the broad economic, environmental, and equity impacts that these new modes of transportation will have on society. The project is motivated by recent advancements in battery technologies, autonomy, and distributed propulsion that are transforming air transportation through the development of a new class of electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft. The development of electric aircraft for longer distances is also in progress and could revitalize and support new service out of regional airports.  The decision support tool can be used by government agencies, aircraft manufacturers, and other stakeholders to guide policy and multi-million dollar public and private infrastructure investments in a way that achieves a balance between economic, environmental, and equity impacts.  

This SBIR Phase I project will push the frontiers in modeling demand for new transportation modes, simultaneously addressing competition with ground modes, competitive pricing, and stimulated demand.  The project focuses on examining how to model competition between air and ground transportation for distances between 50 and 350 miles where air travel has not been economically feasible in the past.  This project focuses on three unproven, high-impact innovations. The first is the design of a scalable, demand simulation platform for air travel that includes distances in which the new aircraft are expected to operate. The second is the development of algorithms that use location-based data to identify the movement of current passengers between airport pairs and to predict demand stimulation. The third is the use of machine learning to calibrate air transportation networks for competitive marketplaces that have hundreds of inputs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project resulted in the development of a software prototype called PassengerSim.  PassengerSim is a competitive analysis tool that allows the airline industry to design, test, and evaluate different business strategies by simulating interactions among multiple competitors within realistic networks. By capturing feedback effects from various revenue management systems used by legacy, low cost and ultra-low-cost carriers, the tool enables airlines to vet and prioritize enhancement ideas, design tests they can run in limited markets to quickly identify potential revenue gains and losses, and reduce the time needed to determine and implement the most effective strategies.

 

With respect to technical merit, several key technical milestones were accomplished in Phase I and include: (1) The implementation and validation of over a dozen industry-standard forecasting and revenue management algorithms. (2) The design and implementation of an API that will enable the integration of existing software tools and users’ custom or proprietary algorithms into PassengerSim. (3) The development of a process to semi-automate the calibration of large input simulation networks tailored to each client’s specific needs, using an innovative approach that combines traditional optimization techniques with advanced machine learning methods. In addition, given the long-term vision of using PassengerSim to support the Advanced Air Mobility community that will introduce electric, hybrid-electric, and hydrogen aircraft into the air transportation system, PassengerSim’s architecture was designed to support modeling passenger demand and competition between ground and air modes distances in which the new aircraft are expected to operate. The project also verified that location-based  data can be used to model air passenger flows in sparsely populated areas of the U.S. where these new aircraft will likely operate.

 

With respect to broader impacts, PassengerSim has the potential to help airlines quickly identify revenue-enhancing strategies, each of which, on average, yields a 0.5% increase in revenues. With global passenger revenues projected to reach over $700 billion in 2024, this could generate an annual economic benefit of about $3.5 billion. Given the highly competitive nature of the airline industry and razor-thin profit margins of about $6 per passenger in 2024, increasing revenues will provide direct benefits to consumers. Because of the highly competitive nature of the industry, increasing revenues for airlines is expected to also increase in investments in operational initiatives that will indirectly reduce operational costs and allow for more efficient resource allocation. These improvements may lead to lower fares, more reliable services, and better on-time performance, ultimately enhancing the passenger experience. Overall, these advancements support a more sustainable and competitive airline industry, benefiting consumers and the broader economy through more affordable and dependable air travel.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2024
Modified by: Alan Walker
